title: How did power plays affect the 2024 playoffs?
text:
Within the standard 60-minute hockey game, there is bound to be a penalty or two from either team. When it comes to playoff time, those penalties are worth even more with the Stanley Cup on the line. The only good that comes from penalties is a trip to the penalty box with an opportunity for a power play for the opposing team.
Power plays can give an advantage to a team for two or five minutes, but that small amount of time can make a big difference in games.
But how much did power plays play into the outcome of the 2024 playoff games?
In reality, not as much as you would think. While power plays give teams what one would assume to be an easier time to score, not every team is able to take advantage of that.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(patchwork)
library(waffle)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggtext)
library(ggplot2)

playoffs <- read.csv("data/nhl_playoffs.csv")
regular <- read.csv("data/nhl_regular.csv")
pergame <- read.csv("data/playoffspergame.csv")

mutatedgoals <- playoffs |>
  mutate(
    RegularGoals = GF - PP.GF
  )

totalgoals <- mutatedgoals |>
  mutate(
    totaledgoals = RegularGoals + PP.GF
  )

ggplot() +
  geom_dumbbell(
    data = mutatedgoals,
    aes(y = reorder(Team, GF), x = PP.GF, xend = RegularGoals),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "#C8102E",
    colour_xend = "#FF4C00")+
  labs(
    title = "Power plays aren't crucial to winning games", 
    subtitle = "<span style = 'color:#C8102E;'>Power play goals</span> helped in the 2024 playoffs, but there were plenty of <span style = 'color:#FF4C00;'>goals scored in regular play</span>",
    x = "Goals", 
    y = "2024 Playoff Teams",
    caption = "Source: NHL | Graph by Krystin Collins"
  ) +  
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_markdown(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  ) 









Power plays are not always as beneficial as one would think. Some teams do better without all players, due to a sense of urgency and fear of becoming vulnerable due to a hole in their defense and offense.
A lot of goals are scored in power plays, but even more are scored in regular play. It ratio is not a close as you would think. Looking at the graph, power plays accounted for roughly 20% of goals in playoff games.
It could be argued that the playoffs have the best of the best teams who don’t have as many penalties. So, maybe regular season play was different.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(patchwork)
library(waffle)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggtext)
library(ggplot2)

playoffs <- read.csv("data/nhl_playoffs.csv")
regular <- read.csv("data/nhl_regular.csv")
pergame <- read.csv("data/playoffspergame.csv")

mutatedgoals23 <- regular |>
  mutate(
    RegularGoals = GF - PP.GF
  )

ggplot() +
  geom_dumbbell(
    data = mutatedgoals23,
    aes(y = reorder(Team, GF), x = PP.GF, xend = RegularGoals),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "#C8102E",
    colour_xend = "#FF4C00")+
  labs(
    title = "Most goals are scored outside of power plays", 
    subtitle = "<span style = 'color:#FF4C00;'>Regular goals</span> accounted for most goals scored in the 2024 regular season, <span style = 'color:#C8102E;'>power play goals</span> didn't hurt though",
    x = "Goals", 
    y = "Teams",
    caption = "Source: NHL | Graph by Krystin Collins"
  ) +  
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_markdown(size = 9.5),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









The regular season wasn’t much different though. There was still a substantial difference between the number of goals in and out of power plays.
The 2024 championship teams, the Edmonton Oilers and Florida Panthers, weren’t making the most out of their power plays. Teams such as the Colorado Avalanche and Dallas Stars, who were also in the playoffs, had more power play goals and goals in regular play throughout the regular season.
???


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(patchwork)

playoffs <- read.csv("data/nhl_playoffs.csv")
regular <- read.csv("data/nhl_regular.csv")
pergame <- read.csv("data/playoffspergame.csv")
penalties <- read.csv("data/nhl_penalties.csv")
individualpenalties <- read.csv("data/individualgamepenalties.csv")

roundtwo <- individualpenalties |>
  filter(
    Team %in% c("Carolina Hurricanes", "New York Rangers", "Boston Bruins", "Florida Panthers", "Dallas Stars", "Colorado Avalanche", "Vancouver Canucks", "Edmonton Oilers")
  )

roundtwo |> summarise(mean(Pen.Drawn, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot() +
  geom_hline(
    yintercept = 3.95,
    color = "#C8102E"
  ) +

    x = "Playoff Dates", 
    y = "Penalties Drawn",
    caption = "Source: NHL | Graph by Krystin Collins"
  ) +  
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_markdown(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  ) 









The graph below looks at the number of power plays averaged in a game, compared to the number of playoff games with, and the size of the dot representing the number of goals while on a power play.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(waffle)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggtext)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggtext)
library(ggrepel)

playoffs <- read.csv("data/nhl_playoffs.csv")
regular <- read.csv("data/nhl_regular.csv")
pergame <- read.csv("data/playoffspergame.csv")

oilers <- playoffs |> filter(Team == "Edmonton Oilers")
panthers <- playoffs |> filter(Team == "Florida Panthers")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = playoffs, 
      aes(
        x = PP.Opp.GP, 
        y = W, 
        size = PP.GF),
      alpha = 0.5
      ) +
  scale_size(range = c(3, 8), name = "Points") +
  geom_point(
    data =oilers, 
      aes(
        x = PP.Opp.GP, 
        y = W, 
        size = PP.GF),
      color = "#FF4C00"
      ) +
  geom_point(data = panthers, 
      aes(
        x = PP.Opp.GP, 
        y = W, 
        size = PP.GF),
      color = "#C8102E"
      ) + 
  geom_text_repel(
    data = playoffs, 
    aes(
      x = PP.Opp.GP, 
      y = W, 
      label=Team,
      size = 1
    )
  )  +
  labs(
    x = "Average Power Plays Per Game",
    y = "Games Won",
    title = "Championship teams made good use of power plays",
    subtitle = "During the 2024 playoffs, Edmonton and Florida used their power plays very effectively",
    caption = "Source: NHL | By Krystin Collins"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    legend.position = "none"
  )









Did teams make good use of power plays when they had them? For the most part, yes.
Especially for the championship teams, Edmonton was averaging 3 power plays a game in the playoffs and scored 22 times in power plays. Florida averaged just under 3.5 power plays a game but only scored 15 goals during that time.

title: Did Adrian Martinez make the right move?
text:
In this day and age, everyone is always looking to the future. It’s all about doing the steps now so that goals can be met later. For collegiate athletes, going pro is a goal of many but it is the steps they take in college that can make or break their post-graduation career.
Adrian Martinez started his collegiate football career at the University of Nebraska before moving to Kansas State in his senior year. At the time, Nebraska was not quite as successful as fans and players had hoped they would be. With that in mind, losing a senior quarterback might not have helped to shift the momentum either.
Transferring that late in a career can be a big risk, but was one Martinez was willing to take. It helped at least some, seeing as he made it on the New York Jets practice squad this fall, but was Kansas State the right move when wanting to pursue a career in the NFL?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(waffle)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggtext)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggtext)

m22 <- read_csv("data/martinez2022.csv")
m21 <- read_csv("data/martinez2021.csv")
nu <- read_csv("data/nebraska2022.csv")
kst <- read_csv("data/kstate2022.csv")

fixedm22 <- m22 |>
  filter(!is.na(PassPct))

passing <- ggplot() +
  geom_line(data=fixedm22, aes(x=Rk, y=PassPct), color="#512888") +
  geom_line(data=m21, aes(x=Rk, y=PassPct), color = "#d00000") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(40,90)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:11, labels = paste( 1:11)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x = "Week", y = "Pass Completion Percentage",
    caption = "Source: https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/adrian-martinez-2.html |Graph by Krystin Collins"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )

rushing <- ggplot() +
  geom_line(data=m22, aes(x=Rk, y=RushAvg), color="#512888") +
  geom_line(data=m21, aes(x=Rk, y=RushAvg), color = "#d00000") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(-3, 20)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:11, labels = paste( 1:11)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x = "Week", y = "Rushing Average Yards",
    title = "Martinez ran further in the Big 12 and passed better in the Big 10",
    subtitle = "His passing was more consistent at <span style = 'color:#d00000;'>Nebraska</span> but his run game was more consistent at <span style = 'color:#512888;'>Kansas State</span>",
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )

rushing / passing









While at Nebraska, Martinez liked to throw the ball and was pretty good at it. His passing game started a lot more consistent at Nebraska, but his passing average was lower at 62.54%. At Kansas State, his pass completion percentage was averaging 64.26%.
Those numbers are a bit deceiving since he only played in nine games in the 2022 season after an injury late in November, but he was on the rise before getting hurt. Martinez only had two games in the 2022 season under 60% in pass completion compared to four in 2021.
He was also running well as a Wildcat compared to his time as a Cornhusker. Martinez averaged 19 yards against Texas Christian and 14.3 yards against Texas Tech in 2022.


Code
combined <- read_csv("data/m2121.csv")

bar22 <- combined |>
  filter(
    School == "Kansas State"
  )

bar21 <- combined |>
  filter(
    School == "Nebraska")

ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = combined, aes(x = reorder(Opponent, PassYds), weight = PassYds), fill="#512888") +
  geom_bar(
    data = bar21, aes(x = reorder(Opponent, PassYds), weight = PassYds), fill="#d00000") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Martinez's arm was always in the air at Nebraska", 
    subtitle = "<span style = 'color:#d00000;'>Nebraska</span> had a passing offense in 2022, <span style = 'color:#512888;'>Kansas State</span> did not",
    x = "Opponent", 
    y = "Passing Yards",
    caption = "Source: https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/| Graph by Krystin Collins"
  ) +  
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









Nebraska liked to throw the ball on offense. Martinez threw for 351 yards against Wisconsin in 2021 and threw over 200 yards in every other game that season. In 2022, he only had three out of the 10 games he was on the field where he threw over 200 yards.
But passing is not the only way to move on the field offensively.
When it comes to rushing yards, Kansas State appeared to be the right spot for Martinez to show off his footwork. He typically rushed for more yards per game but had a few similarities between seasons as well.
At both schools, he had two games where he rushed over 100 yards and one game each where he went negative.


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = combined, aes(x = reorder(Opponent, RushYds), weight = RushYds), fill="#512888") +
  geom_bar(
    data = bar21, aes(x = reorder(Opponent, RushYds), weight = RushYds), fill="#d00000") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x = "Opponent", 
    y = "Rushing Yards",
    title = "Martinez's hit the ground running at Kansas State", 
    subtitle = "<span style = 'color:#512888;'>Kansas State</span> liked to run the ball on offense in 2022, <span style = 'color:#d00000;'>Nebraska</span> not so much",
    caption = "Source: https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/| Graph by Krystin Collins"
  ) +  
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









Overall, Kansas State was the better team. The Wildcats ended the 2021 season at 7-2 while Nebraska ended at 5-4 without ever seeing a bowl game. In 2022, Nebraska once again did not see a bowl game, ending the season at 4-8, while Kansas State improved and went 10-4.
Kansas State had moved the ball more on offense with 445 yards that season and stopped their opponents more on defense, only allowing 375 yards. Nebraska, on the other hand, had almost reverse stats for yardage with 344 offensive yards and 414 yards allowed while on defense.


Code
nu <- read_csv("data/nebraska2022.csv")
kst <- read_csv("data/kstate2022.csv")

nutotalyards <- nu |>
  mutate(
    totalyds = PassYds + RushYds)

ksttotalyards <- kst |>
  mutate(
    totalyds = PassYds + RushYds)
  
nutotal <- c("Defense" = 207, "Offense" = 172, 29)
ksttotal <- c("Defense" = 186, "Offense" = 222)

iron(
  waffle(
  ksttotal, 
  rows = 10, 
  title = "", 
  colors = c("black", "purple")
) +
  labs(
    title = "Kansas State was better than Nebraska in 2022",
    subtitle = "The goal is more offensive yards and less defensive yards"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"),
  waffle(
  nutotal, 
  rows = 10, 
  xlab = "1 square = 2 yards", 
  colors = c("black", "#d00000", "white")
) +
  labs(
    caption = "Source: https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/| Graph by Krystin Collins"
  )
) 









Getting injured is always a risk for athletes and leaves unanswered questions about end-of-season performance. Martinez was playing well, and the Wildcats were winning, but would his NFL career have looked different had he been able to finish out the season?
That answer will remain unknown, but moving to Kansas State put Martinez on a winning offense and a winning team to end his college football career.
